answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/retina-30-2.webp)

This is an optos photograph of the right eye. The vitreous media is clear, and the vessels and nerve appear normal. The most notable abnormality is a well-defined hemorrhage in the macula. Given its well-defined appearance and the presence of overlying blood vessels, the hemorrhage is likely located in the sub-retinal or sub-RPE space. Within the hemorrhage, there appears to be a well-demarcated darker elevated area representing pigment epithelial detachment (green arrow) and an orange nodule suggestive of a polyp (red arrow).

questions.title: Question 2
questions.text:
![](/content/media/retina-30-3.webp)

OCT macula was performed in the right eye, shown to the left. Please describe the OCT macula:

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/retina-30-4.webp)

There is an area of hyper-reflectivity in the sub-retinal space adjacent to large pigment epithelial detachment. Correlating the line scanning ophthalmoscope (LSO) fundus photo with the optos photo, the hyper-reflectivity represents sub-retinal hemorrhage, while the well-demarcated darker area within the hemorrhage likely represents the PED (blue star). A notch sign (short yellow arrow) on OCT represent the organize polyp (green star) seen on fundus photo.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: Indocyanine green angiography (ICGA) was performed demonstrating focal hypercyanescent nodules in the sub-RPE space. Given this, what is the likely diagnosis?

answers.explanation:
Polypoidal choroidal vasculopathy (PCV) was first described in the 1980’s and is characterized by polyp-like, sub-retinal lesions that are best visualized with ICGA. While PCV has traditionally been considered a sub-type of AMD, more recent evidence has identified differences in their clinical outcomes and response to therapy.

Reference: Cheung J.C.H., Ng D.S.C., Lai T.Y.Y. (2020) Polypoidal Choroidal Vasculopathy. In: Kim I. (eds) Macular Disorders. Retina Atlas. Springer, Singapore

questions.title: Question 4
questions.text: The EVEREST trial was conducted to assess the effects of verteporfin photodynamic therapy (PDT) combined with ranibizumab or alone versus ranibizumab monotherapy in patients with symptomatic macular polypoidal choroidal vasculopathy. The EVEREST trial diagnosed PCV based on what criteria?

answers.explanation:
ICGAngiography Hypercyanescence (appearing within the first 5 min of ICG dye injection) and at least one of the following diagnostic criteria:

​- Nodular appearance of the polyp on stereoscopic viewing

\- Hypercyanescence halo around the nodule

\- Abnormal vascular channel(s) supplying the polyps

\- Pulsatile filling of polyps

\- Orange subretinal nodules corresponding to the hyperfluorescent area on ICGA

\- Massive submacular haemorrhage

Reference: Tan CS, Ngo WK, Chen JP, Tan NW, Lim TH, EVEREST Study Group. EVEREST study report 2: imaging and grading protocol, and baseline characteristics of a randomised controlled trial of polypoidal choroidal vasculopathy. British Journal of Ophthalmology. 2015 May 1;99(5):624-8.

questions.title: Question 5
questions.text: In a recent study performed by Chaikitmongkol et al. (JAMA 2019), 4 highly suggestive diagnostic features were identified using fundus photos and OCT in diagnosing PCV. What are the four features?

answers.explanation:
Diagnostic Features: 

​1. Notched or hemorrhagic PED (Notch sign on OCT or hemorrhagic PED)

2. Sharply peaked PED (angle 70 – 90 degrees)

3. Notched or multi-lobulated PED

4. Hyper-reflective ring underneath PED (polyp)

For more information, please refer to the original figure here:

Sensitivity and specificity of potential diagnostic features detected using fundus photography, optical coherence tomography, and fluorescein angiography for Polypoidal Choroidal vasculopathy. JAMA ophthalmology. 2019 Jun 1;137(6):661-7.
